reasoning: The critique targets a real load-bearing subargument: in §2.4.2 the essay leans on antirealism/subjectivism plus many “free parameters” to argue convergence is unlikely, contributing to the overall pessimism about WAM-convergence. However, that branch is not the whole case: the essay also argues (i) even under realism motivation may fail, (ii) various blockers/lock-in issues, and (iii) trade/threat dynamics. So falsifying the antirealist-divergence inference would weaken but not collapse the position (moderate centrality). The substantive pushback—shared post-AGI architectural/decision-theoretic/bargaining constraints could strongly regularize reflection and produce convergence even without moral facts—is plausible and nontrivial, but remains speculative and underargued: it doesn’t show that these constraints uniquely determine values rather than merely constrain instrumental rationality, nor that they deliver the kind of ‘accurate’ moral convergence the essay cares about (moderate-low strength). Most claims are broadly reasonable, though some (e.g., “uniquely stable” impartial aggregation rules) overreach and the ‘reference class failure’ label is not clearly justified (moderate correctness). The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Shared decision-theoretic constraints could drive convergence without objective moral facts
